  • Constructor Details

    • Camera

      public Camera(Point eye, Point center, Vector up, double fovy, int cols, int rows)
      The Camera is the lens through which we look at objects in the Scene. To fully define the Camera's view of the scene we need to: 1) choose a location in World Space for the eye to be located at 2) choose a location in World Space for the eye to be centred on (looking at) 3) rotate the Camera's view clockwise/anti-clockwise until the specified up vector points to the top of the Camera's window screen 4) determine how tall the window screen on which our image is generated using a combination of the vertical field of vision (radians) of the eye and how far the window screen is from the eye 5) decide the resolution of the screen by specifying the number of cols and rows it is to be divided into There is a one to one correspondence between a square on the window screen grid and its respective pixel in the final image.
      Parameters:
      eye - coordinates for the eye in World Space
      center - coordinates for where the eye is focused
      up - vector which decides which direction is "up" when the eye focuses on center
      fovy - the angle of elevation from the eye to the top of the window screen
      cols - number of columns to be drawn on the window screen
      rows - number of rows to be drawn on the window screen

  • Method Details

    • getRay

      public Ray getRay(int col, int row)
      Returns the Ray which originates from the eye and passes through the centre of the square located at the col-th column of the row-th row of the window screen grid.
      Parameters:
      col - the index of the column on the window screen grid through which the Ray passes
      row - the index of the row on the window screen grid through which the Ray passes
      Returns:
      a ray originating from the eye passing through a particular square of the window screen grid

    • getRay

      public Ray getRay(int col, int row, double pixelAdjustmentX, double pixelAdjustmentY)
      Returns the ray which passes through the center of the square on the window screen grid located in the col-th column of the row-th row of the window screen grid. Center of the square is achieved by setting the pixel offset in the x and y directions to be 0.5 of a pixel as there is a one to one correspondence between pixels in the generated image and squares on the window screen grid. x and y are in Camera Space coordinates since they locate a point on the window screen from the eye's perspective. convertCoords(Point) gives the 3-dimensional coordinates of these points in World Space and allows all subsequent computations to be done exclusively in World Space.
      Parameters:
      col - the index of the column on the window screen through which the Ray passes
      row - the index of the row on the window screen through which the Ray passes
      pixelAdjustmentX - horizontal offset of rays on the window screen grid in fractions of a pixel
      pixelAdjustmentY - vertical offset of rays on the window screen grid in fractions of a pixel
      Returns:
      a ray originating from the eye passing through a particular square on the window screen grid

    • convertCoords

      public Point convertCoords(Point p)
      Converts a Point to a Vector with the same coordinates and then see convertCoords(Vector).
      Parameters:
      p - a 3-dimensional point in Camera Space
      Returns:
      a 3-dimensional point in World Space

    • convertCoords

      public Vector convertCoords(Vector v)
      Converts coordinates from Camera Space to World Space. The below matrices are the inverse matrices of the more common matrices found online which go from World Space to Camera Space such as in the slides found at https://www.cs.colostate.edu/~cs410/yr2013fa/more_progress/L12_CamerasRaytracing.pdf. It is not standard matrix-vector multiplication happening in the Matrix.times() method. The vector v is implicitly converted to homogenous coordinate form where the fourth element is the vector's magnitude (in this case magnitude 1).
      Parameters:
      v - vector coordinate in Camera Space
      Returns:
      v's equivalent coordinate when translated to World Space
